params.text:
Read the paragraph and answer the questions below:

Beef Offal:

In the past, when a beast (full beef carcass) was purchased by the butcher, he also received the offal including the head as part of the deal. However about 25 years ago the factories stopped this practice and start selling the offal as an extra. Since then the price of offal has gradually increased in price, this is down to its popularity on the export market.

Ox Tail is very popular for making soup, broth and stew, slow cooking at a low temperature is required.

Beef Liver, although not as popular nowadays, can be found in most traditional butcher shops. Beef liver is an excellent source of iron.

Beef Heart is another offal product which is not as popular as it once was. In the past it was seen as an inexpensive family meal where a large stuffed beef heart would go a long way. More popular with dog owners nowadays (diced and boiled/stewed).

Beef Kidney, still a popular addition in winter dishes such as steak & kidney pies and stews (used to add extra flavor).

Tripe is basically the lining of a cows stomach, honeycomb tripe is from the second stomach chamber (gets its name from the honeycomb design of the interior. Usually cooked in milk.

Ox Tongue is another beef product which is losing popularity. Traditionally tongues were used as a cured meat where they would be skinned and pressed after cooking, they would then be sliced. Popular as a cold meat. Customers from eastern Europe commonly request fresh (unsalted) tongue.

Beef Cheek has made a comeback in popularity in recent years. Delicious when slowly cooked until tender, braised cheeks are also a very popular choice in restaurants.

Lights/Lungs: In the past when all butchers bought full cattle, they received all of the offal parts including the head, the lights/lungs were taken from the pluck and minced for pet food. The lights are an ingredient of the famous Scottish haggis.

*Ox Tail* is very popular for making *soup*, broth and stew, *slow* cooking at a low temperature is required.

Beef *Liver*, although not as popular nowadays, can be found in most traditional butcher shops. Beef liver is an excellent source of *iron*.

Beef *Heart* is another offal product which is not as popular as it once was. In the past it was seen as an *inexpensive* family meal where a large *stuffed* beef heart would go a long way. More popular with *dog* owners nowadays (diced and boiled/stewed).

Beef Kidney, still a popular addition in winter dishes such as steak & *kidney* pies and stews (used to add extra flavor).

*Tripe* is basically the *lining* of a cows *stomach*, honeycomb tripe is from the second stomach chamber (gets its name from the *honeycomb* design of the interior. Usually cooked in milk.

Ox *Tongue* is another beef product which is losing popularity. Traditionally tongues were used as a *cured* meat where they would be skinned and pressed after cooking, they would then be sliced. Popular as a cold meat. Customers from *eastern* Europe commonly request fresh (unsalted) *tongue*.

Beef *Cheek* has made a comeback in popularity in recent years. Delicious when slowly cooked until tender, braised cheeks are also a very popular choice in restaurants.

Lights/Lungs: In the past when all butchers bought full cattle, they received all of the offal parts including the head, the lights/lungs were taken from the *pluck* and minced for pet food. The lights are an ingredient of the famous Scottish *haggis*.
